content.headline: Amazon hit with US labor board complaint over 'joint employment' of drivers
content.summary: Amazon.com has been accused by a U.S. labor board of illegally refusing to bargain with a union representing drivers employed by a contractor, the agency announced on Wednesday.  The complaint from the National Labor Relations Board claims that Amazon is a so-called "joint employer" of drivers employed by the contractor, Battle Tested Strategies (BTS), and used a series of illegal tactics to discourage union activities at a facility in Palmdale, California.  BTS drivers voted to join the International Brotherhood of Teamsters union last year, becoming the first Amazon delivery contractors to unionize.

content.headline: How the port strike will impact the US economy
content.summary: Approximately 45,000 US dockworkers are on strike following the failure of contract negotiations between the International Longshoremen's Association (ILA) and the United States Maritime Alliance (USMX). The deadline for reaching an agreement passed on September 30, triggering the work stoppage. This strike is now affecting operations at 36 ports along the East and Gulf coasts, spanning from Maine to Texas. Yahoo Finance anchor Madison Mills breaks down the situation, exploring the potential economic ramifications of this strike and how the work stoppage could affect consumer goods availability. For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Morning Brief. This post was written by Angel Smith

content.headline: Amazon Persuades Court to Pare Back FTC's Monopoly Lawsuit
content.summary: A federal court late Monday pared back part of the Federal Trade Commission’s lawsuit against Amazon.com that alleges the retailer illegally monopolized the ecommerce market.  U.S. District Judge John Chun granted part of Amazon’s request to dismiss the case early.  Chun issued his order under seal, but the core claims of the agency’s lawsuit appear to have survived the company's challenge, according to an entry in the Seattle court’s docket.

content.headline: Amazon wins partial dismissal of US antitrust lawsuit
content.summary: (Reuters) -Amazon.com Inc won partial dismissal of a U.S. Federal Trade Commission lawsuit accusing it of maintaining illegal monopolies, though the details of the ruling by a federal court in Seattle on Monday were not immediately clear.  The FTC has accused the online retailer of using anti-competitive tactics to maintain dominance among online superstores and marketplaces.  Amazon asked U.S. District Judge John Chun to dismiss the case in December, saying the FTC had raised no evidence of harm to consumers.
